In my view, one of the greatest challenges for climate action today is the difficulty of achieving genuine cooperation among nations. Although there is broad recognition that climate change requires a global response, political and economic interests often prevail over collective responsibility, and different countries assume different levels of responsibility. As a result, agreements are signed but not fully implemented, creating a persistent gap between discourse and action.

International cooperation becomes even more complex when considering asymmetries in development, particularly between the Global North and the Global South. In many countries, especially in Latin America and Africa, climate discussions are not always aligned with urgent social and economic priorities. Means of action may be limited, while some nations hesitate to commit due to concerns over competitiveness and economic impact.

Therefore, I believe the central challenge is to build inclusive governance that protects national interests while promoting common goals, alongside programs that support development in the Global South. For climate action to be effective, a stronger diplomatic effort is essential, coupled with fair financing mechanisms and a renewed sense of multilateral responsibility capable of turning agreements into concrete and measurable actions. Bridging the gap between ambition and implementation is, in essence, a matter of cooperation.

I believe the biggest challenge in climate action today is not a shortage of solutions, but the difficulty of implementing these solutions into every day life. 

We have plenty of climatetech and strategies mapped out on a planetary scale, from our transition to renewables to redesigning our food systems. But implementing and scaling them requires governments, markets, scientists, educators and society to compromise and move in the same direction. With the immense time pressure, it requires a high level of coordination that is incredibly hard in our increasingly fragmented society.

Financing is definitely one of the clearest bottlenecks. Climate adaptation projects in emerging markets are still severely underfunded. Data shows that investors care about sustainability, yet climate risks are still inconsistently priced into valuations, so capital doesn�t always flow to where it�s most needed. As a result, technical solutions dont see the light of day without finance.

But I think the hardest part of implementation is the human dimension. Global cooperation is so hard. The recent COP30 was another reminder of how difficult it is to reconcile collective climate goals with countries national interests. There was overwhelming evidence but countries still disagreed on a firm commitment to phase out fossil fuels. Plus, the climate has so much to do with identity, personal beliefs and ethics. People will inevitably disagree on solutions, if we already disagree on urgency.

The biggest challenge is raising the level of awareness about climate change . Lot of people still downplay the consequences of their actions on the climate . It would be super beneficial to make sure that a wider audience has access to climate change data through interactive sources like documentaires . Another key challenge is the lack of implementation of certain measures that have been adopted during climate summits . The focus on making sure the action points from climate summits are acted upon .

The biggest challenge is the "how" gap. We have countless policies telling us what to do and why sustainability matters. But after all these years, people still don't know HOW to actually implement these ideas.
I see this constantly in my research. Municipalities want to buy sustainably, but they don't know how to write the tender specifications, how to evaluate if a supplier is really sustainable, or how to measure the impact. They have sustainability goals but no practical roadmap to reach them.
This problem is everywhere - companies want to be sustainable but don't know where to start. Cities declare climate emergencies but then continue business as usual because they lack concrete implementation tools.
Through my work with Italian municipalities, I've learned that when you work with people, like "co-designing" approach with the people, they actually start making changes. The motivation is there; what's missing is the practical knowledge.
Another challenge is context - a solution from Milan might not work in a smaller city or in Mongolia. We need to document what works WHERE and WHY, not just copy-paste solutions across different realities.
That's why I focus on the "how" in my research. I document the actual mechanisms, the real processes, the specific tools that municipalities use. Because sustainability isn't about more declarations - it's about showing people exactly how to turn good intentions into concrete actions.

The most significant challenge for climate action today is overcoming the profound systemic inertia that locks our economies, policies, and infrastructure into a fossil fuel dependent. While technological solutions exist, their deployment is slowed by powerful political and economic structures. Short term political cycles, coupled with the influence of incumbent industries and the massive financial investments in legacy assets, create immense resistance to the rapid, coordinated policies needed for a change . This inertia is compounded by social hesitancy and disinformation, creating a gap between public awareness and meaningful action. The main battle is no longer about the science or the tools, but about dismantling these entrenched systems to unlock the large scale, swift change the crisis demands.

One of the biggest climate challenges in the world today is environmental degradation, particularly the loss of forests, pollution of water bodies, and unsustainable land use. These issues are not only global�they directly affect communities in Ghana. In my experience with beach clean-ups in Ada, I�ve seen how plastic pollution and waste harm marine life and local livelihoods. This small-scale example mirrors a larger problem: when ecosystems are degraded, the consequences are felt far beyond the immediate area.

In Ghana, land degradation is particularly severe, destroying water bodies and forest reserves. The impacts are alarming: studies show higher levels of mercury and cyanide in crops, and in some areas, infants are being born with deformities linked to environmental toxins. These local realities highlight how climate change and human activities are creating health crises, food insecurity, and loss of biodiversity�not just in Ghana, but globally.

Addressing this challenge requires coordinated action, from community-level clean-ups like those in Ada to national policies protecting forests, rivers, and soil. Globally, the lesson is clear: without protecting ecosystems and promoting sustainable practices, the effects of climate change will continue to harm both people and the planet.

I think the biggest challenge for climate action today is the gap between political promises and real change on the ground. Many governments and companies announce net zero targets and climate strategies, but finance and infrastructure still support fossil fuels, car based transport and damaging land use. Communities in the Global South, including Pacific Islands, already experience sea level rise, extreme weather, and pressure on food and water, yet they still face complex rules and slow systems when trying to access climate finance and technical support.

This gap is driven by short term political and economic interests, weak accountability for climate promises and limited voice for vulnerable groups in decisions on energy, land, oceans and loss and damage. As long as those who are most affected have the least power in negotiations, climate policies will not match the urgency on the ground. Closing this gap means shifting public and private finance away from fossil fuels, setting clearer rules for accountability, and giving affected communities real influence over decisions, not only consultation. Without this change, climate action will remain uneven and trust will erode further, even if targets look ambitious in official documents.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the lack of a shared understanding of what the most pressing issues are and how they intersect. Different actors often approach climate action from their own perspectives, applying individual assumptions to parts of the problem that are, in reality, not identical. This can lead to fragmented solutions, misplaced priorities, and missed opportunities for collaboration.

For example, in agriculture, some policymakers focus on reducing emissions through technological interventions, while local communities may prioritize soil health, water availability, or crop diversity. Both approaches are valid, but if they are treated as equivalent or pursued in isolation, the outcomes can be limited or even counterproductive. Similarly, global climate finance discussions often center on emission reduction metrics, while the communities most affected by loss and damage prioritize immediate resilience and adaptation needs. Without a common understanding of goals, contexts, and trade-offs, efforts risk talking past each other rather than building meaningful solutions.

Addressing this challenge requires dialogue that bridges local realities, scientific evidence, and policy frameworks. It calls for creating spaces where diverse perspectives are not only heard but understood, and where strategies are co-designed with recognition of the differences in scale, urgency, and impact.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the lack of inclusive and equitable participation in decision-making. Vulnerable groups, including youth, women, and marginalized communities, are often underrepresented, which can result in solutions that overlook local needs and innovative ideas.

Another major challenge is the gap between climate policies and their implementation. Ambitious targets are often slowed by limited funding, weak institutional capacity, and poor coordination, reducing the real impact of initiatives.

Balancing immediate human needs with long-term sustainability is also difficult. Addressing food security, energy access, and economic development while reducing emissions requires complex trade-offs, especially in developing countries like The Gambia.

Finally, misinformation and low climate awareness limit community participation in mitigation and adaptation efforts.

Addressing these challenges requires inclusive policymaking, youth and community engagement, cross-sector collaboration, and innovative approaches. As a youth climate advocate and Gambian Youth Negotiator at COP30, I understand that empowering young people, promoting equitable policies, and connecting global commitments to local action are key to achieving effective, sustainable, and resilient climate solutions.

The world has witnessed several devastating wars in the last few years that made the ambitious Paris Agreement targets slowly hide in the shadows of a rising arms race. I believe that the greatest challenge to climate action is the production of weapons that keeps wars alive and growing along with greenwashing. It is the show of power and hegemony that motivates leaders today which takes climate action out of their agendas. Moreover, warlords and big business players are easily using greenwashing to cover their real ongoing damage to the environment and generations' resources. I can think of The European Green Deal as a great example, we can see how ambitious it seems, but it lacks a true political well and commitment from all stakeholders, because it was lost in the middle of vicious regional wars and 'national security' concerns over the Russian-Ukrainian war and the need to fund military capabilities instead of increasing green incentives or imposing carbon taxes for example.

As the negative effects of climate change like sea level rise, costal erosion, intense hurricanes and flash flooding increase, one of the biggest challenges for climate action today, especially on an industrialized SIDS like Trinidad, is the decarbonization of the industrial sectors that remain economically dependent on hydrocarbons and pollute the environment. T&T's economy is built on natural gas processing, petrochemicals and LNG exports, which sustain national revenue and employment. Transitioning these industries toward low carbon pathways requires not only technology but also financial mechanisms, marking incentives and international cooperation that recognize the unique constraints of developing nations. 

While renewable energy is being adopted at higher rates, the heavy industries pose a deeper challenge due to their high energy intensity and legacy infrastructure. CCUS is an expensive technology to adopt as financing is often limited. Also CBAM has a huge risk creating a trade disadvantage for Global South countries like T&T if we cannot adapt industrial processes to meet global low carbon standards and address climate action. 

A just transition framework is needed that supports industrial innovation though hydrogen integration, green ammonia production and a circular economy where the climate goals are at the forefront of development and citizens can make a sustainable living. 

The Global South must not be left behind in this energy transition.

I believe the biggest challenge for climate action today is the "Equity-Sustainability Paradox." We often frame climate action as a technological or regulatory hurdle, but for the Global South, it is fundamentally a livelihood issue. The conflict lies in balancing immediate economic survival with long-term environmental goals.

Through my research on the gig economy, I see this tension firsthand. Digital platforms optimize logistics and reduce inefficiencies, but they often externalize environmental costs (like vehicle emissions) onto gig workers who lack the capital to transition to green alternatives, such as electric vehicles. The challenge is not just inventing green technology, but ensuring that the transition to a green economy does not exacerbate inequality or destroy the livelihoods of the precarious workforce.

We cannot achieve net-zero goals if the path requires the most vulnerable to pay the highest price. Therefore, the critical challenge is designing inclusive climate interventions�policies and business models that make sustainable practices the most profitable and accessible choice for micro-entrepreneurs and gig workers. Overcoming this requires moving beyond top-down mandates to co-creating solutions with the communities most affected by both economic instability and climate change.

I believe the biggest challenge for climate action today is the gap between scientific knowledge and community-level implementation. Governments, scientists, and international organisations develop policies and research to mitigate climate change, yet these often fail to reach or resonate with those most affected. Communities in vulnerable regions�rural villages, flood-prone areas, informal settlements�face water scarcity, soil degradation, and unpredictable weather. Limited access to information, resources, and practical solutions prevents meaningful participation.

Behavioral inertia and competing socio-economic priorities also hinder action. Many focus on immediate survival, leaving long-term environmental sustainability secondary. Without locally adapted, practical solutions, well-intentioned campaigns may be ignored. Weak regulation enforcement and insufficient funding further undermine national and global goals.

Lack of youth and creative engagement is another barrier. Climate solutions are often technical or abstract, failing to inspire young people or connect with cultural contexts. Storytelling, arts, and community dialogue�tools I use as a poet and climate advocate�bridge this gap, making science relatable, motivating behavioral change, and empowering citizens. Addressing these challenges requires knowledge, education, locally driven solutions, and amplified youth voices. True climate action depends on communities embracing and owning environmental responsibility.

In my own opinion, the biggest challenge for climate action today is funding. At least when I visited the communities in Eastern Uganda, many people knew that there was a change in their climate and environment but had nothing to do.

The more funding we have, the more we shall have climate change addressed.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between scientific knowledge and real policy implementation. Even though we understand the urgency of the climate crisis and have the data and technology to act, political will, financing, and coordination remain insufficient�especially in the Global South, where impacts are already severe. Many governments struggle to turn climate commitments into concrete measures because climate action often competes with short-term economic pressures. At the same time, the communities most affected�coastal populations, informal settlements, small-scale farmers, and youth�frequently lack access to resources, climate information, and participation in decision-making processes that would strengthen their resilience. Another key challenge is that climate action is not equally inclusive. Too often, solutions are designed without meaningful involvement of youth, Indigenous groups, or local actors who understand realities on the ground, weakening governance and slowing progress. Misinformation and low climate literacy also reduce public support for ambitious climate measures, making it harder to build long-term solutions. Addressing these challenges requires stronger political commitment, fair and accessible climate finance, better integration of science into policy, and inclusive processes that elevate vulnerable communities. Closing the gap between knowledge and action is essential for accelerating global climate progress.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today lies in the intersection between behavioural change, economic realities, and governance capacity. Many organizations and governments assume people will choose greener solutions, irrespective of cost. However, behavioural change does not happen in isolation. It is influenced by economic structures, affordability, and access where for many households, clean technologies remain a luxury even though they are environmentally desirable.
This is where governance becomes crucial. Policymaking often focuses on technological supply�renewables, green infrastructure, energy innovation�without understanding the behavioural and socioeconomic factors necessary for widespread adoption. Climate initiatives fail when they ignore deeply rooted inequalities, limited public trust, or lack of supportive institutions. Weak governance and short-term incentives make it harder to bring individual behaviour in line with national climate commitments.
The issue is not only about low-carbon technologies but also about governance systems that facilitate behavioural change from an economic, social, and institutional perspective. Climate action will accelerate only if policy designs account for people's realities�sustainable choices should not only be available, but viable.
I want to keep learning how to use capital not as a mechanism of extraction, but as a tool for climate regeneration, empowerment, & justice. That is the economy I want to help create.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is the growing divide between global climate commitments and the realities faced by vulnerable communities, especially in the Global South. While international frameworks continue to evolve, implementation remains slow due to limited access to climate finance, inadequate technology transfer, and insufficient involvement of frontline communities in decision-making. As a result, regions that experience the most severe droughts, floods, food insecurity, and climate-induced displacement struggle to adapt effectively.

Another major challenge is the fragmentation of climate responses. Climate change cuts across agriculture, health, mobility, and security, yet many interventions remain isolated within single sectors. This makes it difficult to address complex risks such as climate-driven migration or livelihood loss, which require integrated and locally grounded solutions.

Access to climate information also remains uneven. Early-warning systems and climate data are often not translated into actionable formats for rural populations, limiting preparedness and resilience.

Underlying all these issues is a persistent lack of climate justice. Countries and communities that contribute least to emissions continue to be most affected, while having the least influence over global policy decisions.

The biggest challenge for climate action today both in Tanzania and globally is the gap between knowledge and real implementation. Many people, communities, and institutions understand the climate crisis, but turning this awareness into practical, coordinated, and long-term action remains difficult.

In Tanzania, strong policies exist on issues like plastic control, land use, and forest protection, yet enforcement is often weak due to limited resources, slow institutional systems, and competing economic pressures. Communities also depend heavily on natural resources for daily survival, making it challenging to push environmental protection without offering viable alternatives.

Globally, climate action is slowed by unequal responsibility. Countries that contribute the most emissions delay climate financing and commitments, while developing nations struggle to adapt with limited means. Political resistance, misinformation, and short-term economic interests further weaken collective progress.

Another major challenge is that climate action is still treated as a purely environmental issue. In reality, it intersects with governance, social justice, economic models, and community participation. Without inclusive planning, reliable funding, and strong local engagement, climate solutions remain scattered and unsustainable.

The largest obstacle is the growing lack of trust between international climate organizations and the communities that are affected by climate change on a daily basis.  Many rural families, young people, and farmers don't feel connected to policies or promises that seldom result in noticeable change.  Top-down planning, intricate funding structures, and communication that ignores local realities are the main causes of this disparity.  As a farmer and activist, I observe how trust influences everything, including individuals trust those who are present, not far-off organizations.  Even well-thought-out solutions are difficult to accept in the absence of trust.  Climate fatigue is another issue; people want real, tangible improvements in livelihoods, energy access, and food security rather than theoretical objectives.  Meaningful climate progress requires rebuilding trust through community ownership, easier financing, and grounded narratives.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between global commitments and practical implementation on the ground especially in rural communities across Africa. Through my volunteer work with Eukalpton Charity Foundation, I�ve seen how schools and communities understand climate change in theory, yet lack the resources, support, and infrastructure needed to adapt or take meaningful action. This makes the people least responsible for emissions the ones who suffer the most.

Another major challenge is low climate literacy. Many young people and community members I engage with do not fully understand how climate change affects their food systems, health, or future opportunities. Without clear understanding, it becomes harder to inspire behavioural change or build strong community movements for climate action.

Finally, access to funding remains a significant barrier. Grassroots organisations and youth-led initiatives often have innovative ideas, but limited financing slows down their impact.

Addressing these challenges requires stronger policies, more inclusive decision-making, and real investment in community-driven solutions. My experience has shown me that when people are empowered with knowledge and resources, climate action becomes practical, not abstract.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is closing the gap between global ambition and practical implementation. While international agreements set bold targets, translating these into real change on the ground remains difficult. This gap is driven by three interconnected issues: finance, equity, and governance.
First, climate finance is far from adequate and often inaccessible for countries most at risk. Nations like Bangladesh face severe climate impacts but struggle to secure timely and flexible funding for adaptation and resilience. Despite pledges, resources are slow to arrive and burdened with complex conditions.
It is not always about large-scale finance. When I interact with young people in Bangladesh, I see brilliant ideas for climate solutions, but they often lack mentorship or support to scale them. Through the Ecoleaders project, which I lead, we are helping youth turn ideas into action�yet this needs broader systemic backing.
Second, equity is critical. Bangladesh contributes less than 0.3% of global emissions yet bears some of the highest climate risks. Without fair mechanisms for loss and damage, technology transfer, and just transition, climate action risks deepening global inequalities.
Finally, governance and political will remain weak. Short-term economic priorities often overshadow long-term sustainability. In my work, I see communities eager for solutions but constrained by systemic barriers.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the widening gap between global commitments and local implementation. While international agendas, national policies, and high-level climate pledges continue to grow, the translation of these commitments into practical, community-level change remains slow, under-resourced, and uneven, especially in vulnerable regions like the Global South.
A key reason for this gap is that climate solutions are often designed without a deep understanding of local contexts, social dynamics, and existing vulnerabilities. Communities on the frontline, farmers, women, informal workers, elders, and those in fragile and conflict-prone areas are rarely included in decision-making, even though they face the most severe climate impacts. As a result, many interventions remain donor-driven, short-term, or poorly aligned with the realities on the ground.
Another challenge is the lack of accessible finance and technical capacity for low-income countries. Climate funding disproportionately flows to mitigation rather than adaptation, leaving the most climate-vulnerable populations without the resources they need. Meanwhile, data gaps, particularly in remote or conflict-affected areas, limit effective planning, early warning, and long-term resilience building.
Lastly, climate action today is challenged not by a lack of solutions, but by the difficulty of implementing them equitably, sustainably, and at the pace needed to match the accelerating crisis.

One of the challenges I personally experienced is the lack of long-term thinking among many government leaders, especially in democracies where leaders are regularly elected. In the Philippines, it�s a span of three years, and during that period, leaders seek quick and visible solutions to maintain their hold on power. Leaders who intend to look at a wider timeframe risk losing their position, or these initiatives will be halted when new leaders take over. This was my experience in one of our microgrid projects. We provided solar energy to 100 houses and public infrastructure in an upland community. We helped them establish an association for the management and maintenance of the system and assisted the local government in developing a long-term plan. Unfortunately, when the governor changed, the project halted, and the plans were changed.
From a young person�s perspective, this feels quite frustrating. While we see the unavoidable increase in global temperatures, many countries in the global South seem to still be at square one. Recently, our country experienced a series of typhoons, and despite years of experience and preparation for sudden weather changes, the response was to adapt to this as a new norm. In recent events, flood control projects have been compromised, and long-term, nature-based solutions have been overlooked. Thus, there is a need to prioritize climate action and avoid making these initiatives political tools.

As I mentioned in my previous answer, climate action today still circulates within the same sphere as academic data. It does not break out of its theoretical�and sometimes narratively superior�framework to make itself immediate and as relevant as the other issues we are currently facing on a global scale.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between policy commitments and real implementation on the ground, especially in the Global South. While international climate agreements and national policies exist, they often do not translate into tangible support for the communities most affected by climate change. Vulnerable groups such as women, informal settlement residents, and small-scale farmers continue to face floods, droughts, food insecurity, and loss of livelihoods, yet their voices are rarely included in decision-making. Climate action remains heavily dominated by high-level discussions and technical language, making it difficult for ordinary people to engage, contribute, or benefit from climate solutions.

Additionally, climate finance is a major barrier. Although funding commitments are announced globally, accessing these resources is extremely difficult for grassroots organisations, youth groups, and community initiatives that play a critical role in local resilience. The lack of inclusiveness and support for locally-led climate solutions creates inequality in climate adaptation and slows meaningful progress.

To address this challenge, climate action must shift from being only policy-driven to being people-centered, inclusive, and accessible. We need climate solutions designed with and for communities, supported by funding, capacity building, and platforms where local experiences can inform national and global decisions.

With more than seven years of experience as a climate and environmental advocate, I have followed climate talks across international, multilateral, continental, regional, national and local levels. Each level offers a different view of how climate action is progressing.

At the international and continental stages, there is strong technical advancement in research, negotiations and policy design. These platforms set the ambition that should guide national efforts. At the national level, many governments have outlined plans that show an interest in addressing climate change, even if the momentum varies. At the local level, I have seen committed community actors and civil society organizations working hard to create meaningful impact despite limited resources.

Across these levels, one major challenge stands out. The biggest barrier to progress is the inability of governments to turn policies and plans into real, large-scale action. Many commitments remain on paper and are not followed by the urgency needed to match the scale of the crisis.

A clear example is the COP28 declaration in Dubai to triple renewable energy capacity and double energy efficiency by 2030. While this was a strong and positive step, most governments have not taken concrete action to implement it. Because many of these declarations are non-binding, the political will to act remains low, and this slows the global response to climate change.

I think the biggest challenge is both mindset and sacrifice. In UAE, we have a strong convenience culture and a consumer-oriented lifestyle. In Europe, there is more of a mindful consumption, i.e. getting fewer groceries or not needing to have the latest designers. It may sound superficial, but we have already developed and have so many tangible resources and good interventions, but people do not care enough to sacrifice their needs for the global good. This leads to disproportionate climate displacement, harder impacts on Global South i.e. clothing waste in Bangladesh, and it plays into Kant's Categorical Imperative, where if we apply this universally, we don't see change.

In my opinion, the biggest challenge for climate action today is the widening gap between global commitments and the realities faced by communities on the ground. While governments and international institutions have made ambitious pledges, implementation often remains disconnected from the lived experiences of those most affected by climate change. This gap is visible in the Global South, where climate impacts are intensifying but resources are limited. Communities are adapting out of necessity, while disinformation and a lack of climate knowledge communication make it harder to mobilise collective action. Moreover, climate policies are designed in technical ways that overlook the socio-cultural dimensions of climate change among people with intersectional identities. Without addressing justice and inclusion, climate policies risk reinforcing existing vulnerabilities instead of reducing them. Finally, climate action struggles with fragmentation: between sectors, between global and local priorities, and between the urgency of the crisis and the slow pace of policy processes. As a result, communities are left navigating overlapping crises beyond climate change, including socio-economic and digital inequities. To address these challenges, it requires stronger public engagement, clearer communication, and meaningful participation from those most affected, to ensure climate action is people-centred and leads to lasting change.

-Climate action success is being hindered by a number of factors that also vary with countries and continents. For example, in Africa or countries from the Global South, economic challenges seem to be a great challenge. This is because new technologies for climate adaptation such as climate smart-agriculture need resources to implement.
-In addition, lack of knowledge concerning climate change by a number of people from the Global South is acting as a barrier to effective climate action. People are not willing to participate in initiatives that they are not well informed about in terms of causes, processes, effects today and in future. Therefore, there is need for knowledge sharing so that people will make informed decisions.
-Gender inequalities rooted in cultural norms and values stand to be hindering climate action as in many countries form Global South women are not fully participating in decision making processes and have little access to important resources such as land and also education.
-Poor governance and policies by leaders from Global South characterized by corruption obviously affect resource mobilization towards climate action initiatives.

-For countries from the Global North, failure by other countries to reform and commit themselves to climate action is delaying success of climate action. 
-Most initiatives and conferences are led by leaders from Global North such as UNFCCC, yet serious effects are being experienced by people from Global South.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between awareness and meaningful implementation. While knowledge of climate risks and sustainable practices is widespread, translating this awareness into tangible action at local, national, and global levels remains difficult. Policies, funding mechanisms, and technological solutions exist, yet they often fail to reach or effectively engage communities, especially youth and marginalized groups who are most vulnerable to climate impacts. Another significant challenge is the unequal burden of climate change. Communities in the Global South, including Pakistan, face severe consequences from extreme weather, resource scarcity, and environmental degradation, despite contributing minimally to global emissions. This inequity complicates the balance between urgent adaptation needs and long-term mitigation strategies, as immediate survival often takes priority over sustainability.  From my experience leading awareness campaigns, coordinating climate initiatives, and engaging students and volunteers in sustainable projects, I have seen that empowering people with knowledge, tools, and agency is critical to converting awareness into concrete climate action. Only by bridging these gaps can we create lasting, equitable, and scalable solutions to the climate crisis.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is the gap between global discussions and the daily realities faced by people in countries like Nigeria. Climate change is already transforming life for many Nigerian communities through flooding, heatwaves, erosion, and declining food security, yet these experiences seldom influence how policies are created. We hear much about adaptation plans and financial mechanisms, but the people most affected are often absent from the conversations. In Nigeria, climate stress does not occur in isolation. It intersects with weak infrastructure, irregular urban planning, overstretched public services, and deep social inequalities. When flooding prevents children in Bayelsa from attending school or when extreme heat forces informal workers to reduce their daily hours, the core issue is not solely the climate event. It is the absence of a governance system that safeguards the most vulnerable. Climate action struggles when it fails to address these structural issues. Another challenge is representation. Nigeria faces significant climate risks but has limited influence over global climate decisions. When countries with low emissions have little voice in shaping solutions, the resulting policies often fail to address local needs. There is also the issue of trust. Many Nigerians do not feel that climate funding or government plans reach the communities that need them most. Without trust, even the best-designed policies will not succeed in practice.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is making solutions practical and inclusive. While awareness of climate change is growing, many initiatives remain disconnected from the realities of those most affected especially women, youth, and rural communities.

Communities often want to act but lack the tools, knowledge, or resources to do so effectively. Another challenge is the lack of coordination across sectors; climate change is a systemic problem, yet solutions are often fragmented.

I believe that empowering local communities, linking economic opportunities with environmental action, and building long-term resilience are key. By combining education, hands-on projects, and advocacy, we can create sustainable change that lasts.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the widening implementation gap between global commitments and the realities faced by vulnerable communities. Countries have made strong pledges through the Paris Agreement, NDCs, and global adaptation frameworks, but the pace of real on-the-ground action remains too slow to match the scale of climate impacts.

A key driver of this gap is the persistent inequity in climate finance, especially for adaptation. While climate impacts disproportionately affect the Global South, the resources needed to strengthen adaptation finance, technology, and institutional capacity are still limited, unpredictable, or difficult to access. This makes it harder for communities to adapt, for governments to implement plans, and for youth and civil society groups to participate meaningfully in decision-making.

Another challenge is the disconnect between global policy discussions and local realities. Important decisions are often made in international spaces far removed from the people experiencing climate impacts. As a result, solutions may overlook local knowledge, water governance needs, gender dynamics, youth perspectives, and community-led innovations.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between high-level climate ambition and real-world implementation. Policies and targets are becoming more ambitious, but the operational systems that shape emissions; procurement, logistics, waste management, and transport, are still built around cost and speed, not environmental impact. As a result, even well-designed climate strategies often fail to translate into measurable change.

A second challenge is global inequality in climate readiness. Countries in the Global South, including many in the MENA region, face the highest exposure to pollution, extreme weather, and environmental degradation, yet have limited support to modernize their infrastructure or adopt renewable technologies. This slows down climate action where it is needed most.

Another barrier is the fragmented nature of climate governance. Chemicals management, waste policy, energy planning, health, and development are treated as separate issues, even though they are deeply interconnected. Without integrating these systems, especially in rapidly growing regions, climate solutions will remain incomplete.

Finally, climate action is hindered by limited participation from frontline sectors. Logistics, procurement, and humanitarian operations hold enormous potential to reduce emissions and pollution, yet they are often missing from climate conversations. Bridging this gap is essential for accelerating meaningful, systemic change.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the widening gap between scientific knowledge and real-world implementation. We have an unprecedented ability to monitor environmental change, model future risks, and design adaptation strategies yet these insights rarely translate into policies and actions that match the scale and urgency of the crisis.
A major reason for this gap is limited accessibility and usability of climate information, especially for vulnerable communities and local decision-makers. High-quality data exists, but it often remains locked in technical reports, complex models, or institutions that lack the mechanisms to communicate findings effectively. As a result, farmers, urban planners, and local authorities those most exposed to climate risks struggle to make timely, informed decisions.

Another part of the challenge is political and economic inertia. Short-term interests, fragmented governance, and insufficient investment delay transitions in agriculture, water management, and energy systems, even when the scientific evidence is clear. Finally, climate action requires collaboration across disciplines, sectors, and regions something the world still struggles to achieve at scale.

From my experience in climate advocacy so far, I will say it is the lack of genuine awareness in society. Many people hear about climate change, but very few truly understand how it affects their daily lives whether through extreme heat, rising food prices, pollution, or flooding. Because the issue feels distant, it becomes difficult to inspire consistent action or community participation.
This low level of awareness leads to another challenge and that�s climate issues are often not seen as a priority. In places like Nigeria, people are dealing with immediate concerns such as unemployment, insecurity, and rising living costs. As a result, environmental issues are pushed to the background, even though their impacts are already shaping health, agriculture, and livelihoods. Without clear understanding, people struggle to connect these problems to climate change.
And I think this is a result of insufficient public education and communication. Climate messages often remain technical, urban centered, or targeted at the already informed in the society which shouldn�t be. Rural communities, students, local traders, and even young people rarely have access to simplified, culturally relevant information that can help them take action.
When citizens are not fully informed, it becomes harder to demand accountability or influence decision-making.
Overall, the biggest challenge is not the absence of solutions, it is that many people still do not understand why climate action is urgent.

The challenge for climate action today is the fragmentation and volatility of the global landscape. Despite overwhelming scientific evidence and escalating climate impacts, coordinated action is undermined by competing interests. Influential leaders deny climate change or prioritise short-term national agendas, while countries prioritise energy security over sustainability.

This is compounded by the persistent divide between developed and developing nations. Developed countries often shape the global climate agenda, yet developing nations face structural barriers to finance, technology, and capacity-building support. The result is an uneven playing field, where the countries most vulnerable to climate impacts are the least empowered to implement solutions.

Geopolitical self-interest also dominates multilateral discussions, slowing consensus on critical issues such as decarbonisation and equitable climate finance. The lack of a unified purpose not only stalls progress but risks eroding trust among nations who are already facing existential climate risks.

Ultimately, the biggest challenge is political will, and the collective vision, to treat climate action not as a peripheral policy issue, but an urgent, shared responsibility that transcends borders. Addressing this requires bold leadership, equity-focused strategies, and mechanisms that align national interests with global survival, transforming climate action from fragmented ambition into unified, decisive progress.

Inaction to climate change. Climate change is seen as something not important in this generation however, it's impacts shape daily life for many individuals globally with the potential of impacting future generations and the planet. It is critical for everyone to understand climate change and take a step towards climate action for the betterment of humanity and earth since we owe a duty to future generations to protect the earth. Many governments and institutions set ambitious targets, but these often lack the policy mechanisms, financing, or governance structures needed to turn them into real progress.

Without accessible financing, technology transfer, and fair global partnerships, climate action becomes unequal, leaving vulnerable communities behind.

Another critical challenge is the disconnect between policy and people. One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is bridging the gap between scientific knowledge and practical, inclusive implementation. While climate science provides clear evidence of urgent environmental threats, translating this knowledge into effective policies and local action remains uneven, particularly in the Global South. Vulnerable communities often face the greatest impacts but have limited access to resources, decision-making spaces, and awareness programs that would allow them to actively participate in climate solutions.

Another key challenge is fostering collective action across sectors, countries, and generations. Climate change requires cooperation among governments, civil society, businesses, and local communities. Conflicting interests, short-term political priorities, and economic pressures often slow down meaningful action. Misinformation and low awareness further hinder public support for policies and sustainable behaviours.

To be effective, climate action must also be equitable and socially inclusive, addressing inequality while protecting the environment. Solutions disconnected from social realities risk leaving the most vulnerable behind.

I believe these challenges can be addressed through inclusive policymaking, youth leadership, and community engagement. By connecting scientific insights, local realities, and global cooperation, climate action can become more effective, resilient, and impactful for people and the planet.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between ambition and implementation. Many governments commit to strong climate targets, but the policies, financing, and institutional capacity needed to achieve them remain limited. This gap is especially visible in regions highly exposed to climate impacts, such as the Middle East and North Africa, where water scarcity, heat extremes, and rapid urbanisation increase vulnerability.

Insufficient climate finance and slow technology transfer make it difficult for developing countries to adapt or scale innovative solutions. Many climate technologies�such as renewable energy storage, efficient irrigation, or atmospheric water harvesting�remain inaccessible or unaffordable. At the same time, communities often lack the information or support needed to adopt climate-resilient practices, which limits public acceptance and slows local implementation.

Without stronger political will, investment, and international cooperation, the transition from high-level commitments to real on-ground change will remain too slow to match the speed of the climate crisis.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between ambitious global pledges and the limited, often unclear implementation behind them. Many countries and companies announce strong climate goals, but these rely on vague plans, weak reporting, and unreliable offsets, allowing greenwashing to grow and making progress hard to measure.
This challenge is intensified by the divide between developed and developing countries. Developed nations, despite contributing most to historical emissions, often shape climate rules in ways that protect their interests. Limited technology sharing, unfair carbon markets, and resource extraction practices place heavier burdens on developing countries. This slows cooperation and restricts sustainable development in regions already facing high climate vulnerability.
Communities in the Global South experience the worst climate impacts but receive the least climate finance, technology access, and institutional support. Without fair resources, global climate action remains unequal and less effective.
A new challenge is the rise of digital technologies and AI, which increase energy use and create emerging emissions that current climate frameworks do not fully address.
Overall, the biggest challenge is ensuring that climate action is credible, fair, and inclusive. Real progress requires transparency, accountability, and genuine support for developing countries so climate action leads to shared and meaningful results.

The main barrier to effective climate action is the widening gap between global ambition and local reality. This paralysis is compounded by an information ecosystem that provides fragmented, overly technical data rather than practical guidance, and a governance structure where global policies are crafted without the representation of those most affected, such as farmers, women, and informal workers. This exclusion creates a cycle where financial and political support fails to reach the grassroots innovators and community organizations best positioned to drive adaptation, leaving the most vulnerable behind.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is the gap between global commitments and the realities faced by communities on the ground, especially in fragile and conflict-affected areas. While international policies focus on long-term goals, communities in places like Darfur face urgent problems such as displacement, food insecurity, water scarcity, and weak institutions. These challenges make it difficult to implement climate solutions effectively.

Another key challenge is the lack of meaningful inclusion of women, youth, and local communities in climate decisions. Those most affected by climate change often have the least power to influence policies or access resources.

Climate finance is another barrier. Funds are often delayed, complex to access, or do not reach the communities that need them most. Political instability, bureaucracy, and lack of technical support leave vulnerable populations without the tools to adapt.

To overcome these challenges, climate action must focus on local needs, involve affected communities in decision-making, and link environmental solutions with social justice, economic recovery, and peacebuilding. Empowering women and youth to lead initiatives and giving them access to resources is essential for effective, sustainable, and inclusive climate action.

One of the biggest challenges facing climate action today is the gap between awareness and implementation. Although many institutions and governments recognize the seriousness of climate change, translating this awareness into practical, long-term solutions is still slow. Limited funding, weak policy enforcement, and competing development priorities often hinder progress, especially in developing countries. Another major challenge is the lack of community-level engagement and climate education. Local communities, who are most affected by climate impacts, often lack the information, resources, and support needed to adopt climate-resilient practices. Inadequate collaboration across sectors also slows down the design of effective adaptation strategies. Planners, researchers, policymakers, and community groups must work together, yet coordination is often weak. Additionally, the world�s continued dependence on fossil fuels and the slow transition to renewable energy continue to worsen climate impacts. Until countries accelerate the shift to cleaner energy and sustainable development pathways, climate action will remain limited. Addressing these challenges requires strong governance, community empowerment, equitable financing, and inclusive partnerships.

One word? Indifference. I live in Khulna in southern Bangladesh, a region known for the Sundarbans, the world�s largest mangrove forest. Several rivers run through the city, yet the roads and residential areas flood every rainy season. Much of the rivers� space has been occupied by politically powerful groups, and market waste and industrial discharge are regularly dumped into the water. The rivers also desperately need dredging. This is the reality I see around me.

In my view, people already know what is right for the environment and what harms it. But for short-term profit, they choose not to act. Environmental damage does not strike back immediately; its process is slow. Because of this delay, we allow the slow violence to continue. I believe our indifferent attitude is the main challenge to effective climate action today.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is bridging the gap between policy ambition and public behaviour. While EU and national climate policies are increasingly ambitious, societal inertia, low awareness, and disinformation often undermine their effectiveness. Even when citizens support climate action in principle, habits, cognitive biases, and perceived social norms can limit meaningful engagement.
This challenge connects directly to my master�s thesis, where I studied how dynamic norm information can encourage climate-friendly behaviour. My research showed that people are more likely to act when they see others around them taking action, emphasizing the importance of communication, trust, and social influence.

Addressing this challenge requires not only clear, transparent policies but also strategies to foster behavioural and cultural change, counter misinformation, and increase public legitimacy. My experience supporting EU Member States on Social Climate Plans has shown me how public acceptance can make or break policy implementation. Similarly, engaging international partners highlights that climate action must consider diverse social contexts to succeed. Strengthening this social foundation is therefore essential for achieving climate neutrality globally.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the lack of adequate and accessible financing for the most vulnerable countries. Nations like Chad face growing climate impacts extreme heat, droughts, and water scarcity yet they receive only limited support to adapt. Without predictable funding, it is difficult to scale renewable energy solutions, strengthen community resilience, or protect essential ecosystems.

Another major challenge is the limited voice that climate-vulnerable countries have in global decision-making. Those who contribute the least to global emissions are often absent from key negotiation tables, meaning their priorities adaptation, water security, and loss and damage are not fully reflected in international policies.

Capacity constraints also slow progress. Many countries lack the technical resources, research tools, and institutional support needed to design and implement effective climate strategies. This is why initiatives like Ideas Lab, which strengthen skills and expand networks, are so valuable.

Finally, global climate action still suffers from the absence of strong enforcement mechanisms for major polluting nations. Without clearer obligations and accountability, emissions continue to rise despite repeated commitments.

Achieving real progress requires fair financing, stronger inclusion of Global South voices, and international policies that ensure responsibility and results.

The greatest challenge to climate action today is in my opinion two-fold, that is declining political will and uncoordinated global effort. The effects of climate change are felt universally. However, some countries have contributed more to global emissions than others. The countries with lower contributions to global emissions are seen to suffer more from climate change. There is a thus a push and pull on who should be most involved in climate action. Politically for example, at the start of 2025, the United States administration made its intentions to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. Media reported that President Trump also intended to approve new drilling and new pipelines. Uganda has also been faced with criticism for its dependence on fossil fuels especially with the plans for exploration of the newly discovered reserves. These examples from the United States (a developed country) and Uganda (a developing country) undermine the efforts discussed at the Conference of Parties (COP) to facilitate a global transition from fossil fuels. They show the discoordination in global efforts towards climate action. Without coordination, the wins of certain countries are continuously watered down by the inaction in other countries. 
In Uganda for example, there seems to be a lack of clear definition of roles and responsibilities hindering decision making, reporting and tracking. Within civil society, there is duplication of efforts clouding climate space without significant results.

I believe the most significant challenge is the "justice and implementation gap." While technology and policy frameworks exist, we are failing to ensure a just, equitable, and locally relevant transition. The impacts of climate change and the costs of adaptation are disproportionately borne by the most vulnerable and historically marginalized communities, who contribute the least to the problem.

In the context of my region, the pacific islands, the triple threat posed by climate change is the biggest challenge to the people. Rising sea levels, ocean acidification and ocean warming not only pose a serious risk to our islands but they have already started to swallow up atolls and smaller islands, causing displacement and forced migration.

For me, the biggest challenge in climate action today is the gap between high-level commitments and what actually reaches communities on the ground. I see this every day in my work with small-scale farmers. Many of them know the climate is changing, but they don�t have access to reliable information, practical training, or the basic tools that would help them adapt. Even when policies sound good on paper, the support rarely filters down in a way that fits their realities.
Another challenge I�ve experienced is that climate funding is often complicated, slow, and geared toward large organizations. Community groups or youth-led initiatives like ours at the Polly Foundation struggle to access even small grants that could make a big difference.
There�s also a disconnect between technical climate processes and the people meant to benefit from them. For example, in standards work with ISO, KEBS, and SBTi, I often see how complex terminology and frameworks can discourage smaller actors from participating or even understanding how these systems affect them.
Finally, youth engagement has improved, but young people are still invited mostly for visibility rather than for real decision-making. It�s hard to drive meaningful change when young people have energy and ideas but limited influence over budgets or policies.
So in my view, the challenge isn�t a lack of ideas but rather it�s the difficulty of turning commitments into practical, accessible, and community-centered action.

For me, one of the biggest challenges in climate action today is the painful gap between what the world promises and what actually reaches the people who need help the most. Coming from West Africa, I have seen how climate change affects everyday life, not through big headlines, but through rising food prices, unpredictable weather that threatens livelihoods, and the quiet struggles of communities with very limited support systems. Global commitments like the Paris Agreement sound ambitious, yet the resources needed to implement them rarely trickle down to the most vulnerable.

This disconnect makes climate change feel like an unfair burden on communities that contribute the least to the crisis. Young people, especially women and those in informal settlements, face the harshest consequences but are almost never invited into the spaces where solutions are being designed. Their lived experiences are treated as footnotes instead of guiding voices.

Another challenge I see is that climate policy discussions often happen far away from the realities of those directly affected. Solutions are developed with good intentions but without the cultural, social, or economic context needed for them to work on the ground.

Finally, political hesitation, misinformation, and short-term economic priorities make it difficult to act with the urgency the moment demands.
Addressing these challenges requires more than money or technology, it requires listening.

One of the greatest challenges in climate action today is the human impact of environmental changes, especially in vulnerable communities where climate pressures such as drought, water scarcity, and rising temperatures drive young people toward irregular migration.

The main challenges lie in translating climate policies into tangible solutions and enabling communities to cope with environmental risks. Young people often lack resources or sufficient awareness, making migration appear to be the only option when climate conditions become difficult.

Empowering youth to understand climate risks and make responsible decisions is therefore a critical challenge. Through awareness programs and innovative tools such as Virtual Reality, young people can visualize the link between environmental pressures and migration, make informed choices, and strengthen resilience within their communities.

Addressing climate challenges requires an integrated approach that combines policy, education, and community engagement, with a focus on building resilience and reducing the drivers of irregular migration.

The persistent gap between global ambition and actual implementation is one of the biggest challenges.  A core part of this challenge lies in governance and coordination.  Another major obstacle is the financing gap, especially for adaptation. 
A third critical challenge is the exclusion of youth and local communities from decision-making. Young people are leaders in innovation, mobilization, and climate literacy, yet they are still underrepresented in formal negotiations, regional cooperation frameworks, and national policy processes. Without integrating their perspectives, climate action risks being disconnected from the realities and solutions emerging on the ground.
Addressing these intertwined challenges is key to transforming commitments into real, sustainable change.

I think the biggest challenge for climate action today is a combination of behaviour change, financial limitations, and limited access to technology. Many people still struggle to change their daily habits, even when they know the effects of pollution and environmental damage. At the same time, many communities lack the money needed to support strong climate initiatives such as renewable energy, waste management, or large-scale conservation projects. Technology that could help solve climate problems is often unavailable or too expensive for developing regions. These challenges slow down progress and make it difficult to implement long-term solutions. I believe this is serious because we already see many negative effects on the environment, including extreme weather, pollution, and loss of natural resources. Without solving these issues, climate action will continue to move slowly, and the impacts will become harder to reverse.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is the growing gap between global commitments and actual implementation. Countries, institutions, and corporations often make ambitious pledges, yet these commitments rarely translate into the scale, speed, or consistency required to keep warming within 1.5�C. This implementation gap is driven by three interconnected issues.

First is inadequate financing. Many vulnerable regions, especially in the Global South, lack the resources to transition to clean energy, build resilient infrastructure, or respond to climate shocks. Without predictable and accessible climate finance, even the most well-designed plans stall.

Second is political hesitation. Climate policies often clash with short-term economic or electoral interests. As a result, leaders delay tough decisions such as phasing out fossil fuel subsidies or enforcing emissions standards, even when the science is clear.

Third is the lack of integration across sectors. Climate impacts cut across energy, agriculture, health, and security, but many responses remain siloed. This limits the kind of transformative change needed to address the crisis.

Overall, climate action is not limited by technology or knowledge,those already exist. The real challenge is building the political will, financing capacity, and cross-sector coordination necessary to turn commitments into sustained, measurable action.

One of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between scientific knowledge and societal implementation. We have extensive evidence on the impacts of climate change and effective solutions, yet political, economic, and social barriers slow meaningful action. Short term economic interests often outweigh long term sustainability goals, and unequal responsibilities between nations create tensions in global agreements. Additionally, public awareness does not always translate into systemic change, as policies and infrastructure often lag behind urgent needs. This makes coordinated, large scale action difficult, despite the clear and growing risks to ecosystems, communities, and the global economy. Bridging these gaps requires innovative policy, inclusive governance, and collective societal commitment.

In Malawi, one of the biggest challenges for climate action is the lack of affordable and accessible alternatives to charcoal and firewood. Most households cannot afford gas, electric stoves, or other clean cooking technologies, so they continue to depend on wood-based fuel for daily cooking. Even when people understand the impact of deforestation, the cost of cleaner options is simply out of reach.

Poverty also forces many young people to produce and sell charcoal as a source of income. For families with no stable employment, charcoal-making becomes one of the quickest ways to earn money, even though it destroys forests. Without real economic alternatives, communities will keep cutting trees faster than they are replanted.

Another challenge is the lack of interest in tree-planting as a continuous habit. Many people see it as a one-day activity rather than something to maintain until seedlings survive. This mindset leads to low survival rates and limited long-term impact.

Weak enforcement of forestry laws and limited community ownership over forests also make it difficult to protect areas like Chikangawa Forest and Kasasile Village, which were once heavily forested but have now lost most of their trees.

Overall, Malawi�s climate challenge is a mix of energy poverty, lack of alternatives, economic pressure, and weak environmental stewardship�issues that must be addressed together to create lasting change.

The biggest challenge for climate action today is the absence of reliable, inclusive communication channels between governments and local communities. When decision-makers lack direct, structured feedback from the people experiencing climate impacts, policies often fail to respond to real needs on the ground. local challenges are often poorly addressed because there are few effective networks that allow officials and residents to exchange information openly and consistently. Without these networks, governments cannot accurately identify priorities, and communities cannot effectively voice their concerns or gain access to the resources meant for them. In Nutshel, the biggest challenge for climate action is bridging the communication gap between government institutions and the communities they serve, so that climate solutions are locally informed, timely, and effective.

The disconnect between climate science, policy, and community-level implementation. While research provides clear evidence of the urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to changing climates, translating this knowledge into effective policies and actionable strategies remains a major hurdle. This gap is particularly pronounced in the Global South, where limited resources, capacity constraints, and competing development priorities can hinder the adoption of sustainable practices.
Another challenge is inequity in climate responsibility and impact. Those who have contributed least to global emissions often vulnerable communities in developing countries face the most severe consequences, including food insecurity, water scarcity, and extreme weather events. Addressing climate change therefore requires not only technical solutions but also a strong focus on justice, equity, and inclusive decision-making.
Finally, public engagement and behavior change continue to be difficult. Policies and innovations can only succeed if communities understand, accept, and actively participate in climate solutions. Bridging the gap between knowledge and action demands education, awareness, and empowerment of youth, women, and local stakeholders.

In The Gambia, one of the biggest challenges for climate action today is the gap between strong policy commitments and the limited capacity to implement them effectively. Working as a Program Assistant at the National Environment Agency, I see firsthand how coastal erosion, marine pollution, and flooding threaten communities, yet resources, technical expertise, and coordination across institutions remain constrained. Even when youth groups, civil society, and government actors are mobilized, sustaining momentum and translating dialogue into concrete, funded action is difficult.
From my experience coordinating multi-stakeholder initiatives, including youth conferences, clean-up campaigns, and sensitization programs, I have learned that climate action falters when collaboration is fragmented and when vulnerable voices are not fully integrated into decision-making.
Globally, this challenge is mirrored in the disconnect between ambitious international pledges and the realities of local implementation. Financing, technology transfer, and inclusive governance remain uneven, leaving frontline countries like The Gambia exposed. The greatest obstacle is not a lack of awareness but the ability to bridge commitments with practical, equitable solutions that empower communities and institutions alike. Strengthening accountability, building capacity, and ensuring that climate action is inclusive are, in my view, the most pressing challenges for the world today.

I believe the biggest challenge for climate action today is bridging the gap between knowledge and action. We have more information than ever about climate change, yet turning that knowledge into meaningful action remains difficult. This gap is visible worldwide, including in my home country, Tunisia. In Gabes, severe pollution from a phosphate-processing plant has damaged air, water, and the coastline. Through my work on climate data projects and volunteering in beach clean-ups, I�ve seen both sides of this challenge.
